summary_points: 1. On May 15, 2025, Fortive Corp.'s subsidiary, Ralliant Corporation, entered into a credit agreement with a syndicate of banks for a total credit facility of $2,050 million, comprising term loans and a revolving credit facility.

2. The interest rates on the credit facilities range from 0% to a variable rate based on SOFR or the prime rate, plus a margin dependent on Ralliant's Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio and credit rating, with quarterly testing commencing September 26, 2025.

3.  Ralliant plans to use part of the term loan proceeds to fund a cash distribution to Fortive for the transfer of assets and liabilities of Fortive’s Precision Technologies segment, with remaining funds allocated to working capital and general corporate purposes.
1. Larry O'Reilly resigned from the O’Reilly Automotive Inc. Board of Directors on May 15, 2025, due to the company's mandatory retirement age policy.
2.  Shareholders approved a 15-for-1 stock split, increasing the number of authorized shares from 245,000,000 to 1,250,000,000.
3. A shareholder proposal to improve the clawback policy for unearned executive pay was rejected by shareholders on May 15, 2025.

1. On May 16, 2025, Southwest Airlines amended its bylaws to restrict shareholder derivative lawsuits, requiring a 3% ownership stake to pursue such actions and mandating specific court venues in Texas, waiving jury trials.
2.  These bylaw changes, prompted by amendments to the Texas Business Organizations Code, may make shareholder lawsuits against Southwest Airlines more expensive and difficult.
3. The SEC filing contains numerous instances of what appears to be corrupted or unreadable data, potentially impacting the reliability of reported information.

1. At Marsh & McLennan Companies, Inc.'s annual meeting on May 15, 2025, 90% of outstanding common stock was represented, voting on director elections, executive compensation (non-binding), auditor ratification, and an amended stock award plan.

2.  Significant shareholder opposition was present in the director elections, with Morton O. Schapiro receiving 41,999,985 votes against his election and Steven A. Mills receiving 30,590,863 votes against his election.
3.  The Amended and Restated 2020 Incentive and Stock Award Plan was approved, with 8,297,160 shares voted against the plan.

1. Southwest Airlines Co. held its Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 14, 2025, where shareholders voted on the election of thirteen directors, executive compensation, ratification of independent auditors, and an amendment to the clawback policy.
2.  The shareholder proposal to amend the clawback policy for unearned executive pay received 21,779,309 votes for and 404,403,087 votes against, indicating significant opposition to the proposal.
3. The filing indicates Ernst & Young LLP was ratified as the company's independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.

1. On May 19, 2025, Extra Space Storage Inc. announced the retirement of its CFO, P. Scott Stubbs, effective December 31, 2025, and the appointment of Jeff Norman as his successor, starting July 1, 2025.
2.  Mr. Norman's annual base salary will be $450,000, and he will receive a restricted stock grant valued at $300,000 upon his appointment as CFO.
3. Mr. Stubbs' retirement and Mr. Norman's promotion were publicly announced via a press release on May 19, 2025.
1. On May 14, 2025, Pfizer Netherlands International Finance B.V., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Pfizer Inc., issued €3.35 billion in senior unsecured notes due between 2029 and 2045.
2.  The notes were sold at a discount to the public, with the 2032 notes being offered at 99.263% of face value and purchased by underwriters at 98.863%.
3.  Pfizer Inc. fully and unconditionally guaranteed the notes, which may be redeemed in whole or in part at the option of the issuer.

1. Vertex Pharmaceuticals has announced a new $4.0 billion common stock repurchase program (the "2025 Repurchase Program"), in addition to the $775 million remaining from the 2023 program, allowing for a total of $4.775 billion in potential repurchases.
2. As of May 16, 2025, $775 million remained available under the previous $3.0 billion stock repurchase program authorized in 2023.
3. The 2025 Repurchase Program has no expiration date and can be halted at any time, depending on market conditions and other investment opportunities.
1. On May 15, 2025, Cencora, Inc. agreed to issue and sell €1 billion aggregate principal amount of senior notes due 2028 and 2032.
2. The company expects to receive net proceeds of approximately €994.0 million from the sale, intended for general corporate purposes.
3.  Certain underwriters and their affiliates have provided, and may in the future provide, various financial services to Cencora, Inc., creating potential conflicts of interest.

1. American Water Works Company, Inc. has entered into a Purchase and Sale Agreement to acquire regulated water and wastewater assets for approximately $315 million, adding nearly 47,000 customer connections.
2.  The acquisition is expected to close by August 2026, but this is contingent upon regulatory approvals and other customary closing conditions.
3. If the Purchase Agreement is terminated under certain conditions before closing, American Water will be required to pay a $15,750,000 termination fee.
1. At Invitation Homes Inc.'s 2025 annual meeting (May 15, 2025), 90.64% of issued and outstanding shares voted.
2.  Deloitte & Touche LLP was ratified as the independent registered public accounting firm for 2025, with 547,627,807 votes for, 7,866,980 votes against, and 44,315 abstentions.
3.  Stockholders approved annual non-binding advisory votes on executive compensation, aligning with the board's recommendation (next required vote on frequency in six years).

1. Motorola Solutions, Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders on May 15, 2025, where shareholders elected all nominated directors and ratified PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for 2025.

2.  Shareholder approval of executive compensation was advisory and received significantly less support (106,626,579 "for" votes) than the ratification of the accounting firm (149,379,849 "for" votes).
3. Effective May 15, 2025, Motorola Solutions, Inc.'s Board of Directors was reduced to seven members, and Nicole Anasenes was appointed Chair of the Audit Committee.
1. On May 19, 2025, Akamai Technologies Inc. completed a $1.725 billion offering of 0.25% Convertible Senior Notes due May 15, 2033.
2.  Akamai used approximately $300 million of the notes' proceeds to repurchase 3,870,468 shares of its common stock at $77.51 per share.
3.  The notes are convertible into shares of Akamai's common stock at an initial conversion price of approximately $93.01 per share, representing a 20% premium to the May 14, 2025 closing price.
1. On May 19, 2025, Equinix, Inc.'s subsidiary issued €750,000,000 of 3.250% Senior Notes due 2029 and €750,000,000 of 4.000% Senior Notes due 2034, fully guaranteed by Equinix, Inc.
2.  The net proceeds from the offering of the notes will be used to finance or refinance green projects, or for general treasury purposes, including repayment of existing borrowings.

3.  The indentures contain customary terms allowing the trustee or holders of at least 25% of the notes to declare the principal and accrued interest immediately due and payable upon certain events of default.

1. At PPL Corp's May 16, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, a proposal for an independent evaluation of greenhouse gas reduction targets was rejected by a vote of 42,764,723 for and 548,711,255 against.
2. All ten director nominees were elected, with the lowest number of "For" votes received by Keith H. Williamson (576,814,541) and the highest by Linda G. Sullivan (592,429,316).
3. Deloitte & Touche LLP was ratified as PPL Corp's independent registered public accounting firm for the year ending December 31, 2025.
1. Bunge Global SA's shareholders approved a $2.80 per share cash dividend, payable in four installments, at their May 15, 2025 Annual General Meeting.
2. Linda Jojo was appointed to Bunge's Board of Directors, effective May 15, 2025, until the 2026 annual general meeting; her expertise is in business technology and cybersecurity.
3.  The appointments of Anne Jensen, Adrian Isman, Christopher Mahoney, and Markus Walt to the Board are contingent upon the closing of the Viterra Limited acquisition.
1.  No new information is present in the provided text.

1. Kimberly-Clark Corporation voluntarily delisted its common stock from the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on May 29, 2025, and transferred the listing to Nasdaq, where it will continue trading under the symbol "KMB" starting May 30, 2025.
2.  The company amended its By-Laws on May 19, 2025, to remove certain NYSE-specific details regarding committees,  which are now addressed in committee charters.
3. The company's SEC filing identifies risks associated with the stock listing transfer, including potential delays, market disruptions, and negative impacts on its business operations.

1. Wabtec US Rail, Inc. became an additional guarantor of Westinghouse Air Brake Technologies Corporation's outstanding US Notes, as of May 19, 2025, due to its existing guarantee of a credit agreement with the company.

2.  For the three months ended March 31, 2025, the combined Parent Company and Guarantor Subsidiaries reported $1,532 million in net sales and $33 million in net income;  while for the year ended December 31, 2024,  net sales were $5,949 million and net income was a loss of $104 million.

3. The filing includes guarantor summarized financial information (Exhibit 99.1) reflecting the addition of Wabtec US Rail, Inc., showing a significant reduction in combined net income from the fiscal year end to the subsequent quarter.

1. Interstate Power & Light Company (IPL), a subsidiary of Alliant Energy Corporation, completed a public offering of $600 million aggregate principal amount of its 5.600% Senior Debentures due 2035 on May 19, 2025.

2. IPL intends to use the net proceeds from this offering to retire existing debt, reduce outstanding capital under its receivables program, reduce commercial paper, and for general corporate purposes.
3. Legal opinions from Perkins Coie LLP and Simmons Perrine Moyer Bergman PLC, dated May 19, 2025, confirm the legality of the debentures under relevant laws.
1. Steven D’Ambrosia, Altria's Vice President and Controller, retired on July 31, 2025, and Katie F. Patterson was appointed as his replacement, effective the same date.

2. At Altria's 2025 Annual Meeting, shareholders approved the 2025 Performance Incentive Plan, reserving 25 million shares, and the 2025 Stock Compensation Plan for Non-Employee Directors, reserving 1 million shares.

3.  Ms. Patterson's annual base salary will be $300,000, with additional compensation targets consistent with current salary band F targets (50% of base salary for annual incentives, $112,900 LTIP target, and $165,000 equity award target).
1. Ball Corporation completed a €850 million public offering of 4.250% Senior Notes due 2032 on May 19, 2025.
2.  The Notes are senior unsecured obligations of Ball Corporation, fully guaranteed by substantially all of its domestic subsidiaries.
3.  In a change of control repurchase event, Ball Corporation is required to offer to purchase the Notes at 101% of the principal amount plus accrued interest.

1. On May 18, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) agreed to sell its ZT Group Int’l, Inc. subsidiary's data center infrastructure manufacturing business to Sanmina Corporation for $3.0 billion, including potential contingent consideration of up to $450 million.

2.  The transaction is expected to close near the end of 2025, contingent upon regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions;  if not completed by May 18, 2026 (with possible extensions), Sanmina will pay a termination fee of up to $153 million.
3. AMD will retain ZT Systems' design and customer enablement teams, and Sanmina will become a preferred manufacturing partner for AMD's cloud rack and cluster-scale AI solutions.
1. Discover Financial Services completed its merger with Capital One Financial Corporation on May 18, 2025, resulting in Discover ceasing to exist as a separate entity.
2.  Discover common stock was delisted from the NYSE on May 19, 2025, and Capital One intends to file for its deregistration.

3.  Gross-up agreements were approved on May 16, 2025, to reimburse certain Discover employees for excise taxes related to “excess parachute payments” under Section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code, with a total cap of $25,000,000.
